search_result.title: Here's what Milwaukee area school districts are planning for ...
search_result.text:
The Glendale-River Hills, Greenfield, Nicolet, Shorewood, South Milwaukee, St. Francis and West Allis-West Milwaukee school districts, along with Milwaukee Public Schools, are starting the year virtually, while many schools in the suburbs are planning to start the school year in person with remote options available.

Here's how schools around the Milwaukee area are handling reopening in the age of the coronavirus.

This list will be updated as additional information becomes available.

Arrowhead Union High School District

Families can choose between attending school five days per week through in-person learning or five days per week through virtual learning. The determination will be for one quarter.

Students who test positive for COVID-19 will be required to do virtual leaning until it is safe to return.

Students must wear masks when in school. Masks can only be removed for eating and some limited physical activities. Students also need to do self-health check every 24 hours.

Brown Deer School District

Families in Brown Deer will choose between a full virtual learning option or a five-phase gradual return to face-to-face learning.

The first day of school will be Sept. 1 and all students K4-12 will start learning virtually from home. On Sept. 21, which is Phase 2, students in grades K4-5, 6 and 9 will return to school two days a week and learn virtually three days a week, while students in grades 7, 8 and 10-12 will continue with all virtual learning. The plan further details three more phases to return more students to school and for more days, which will depend on the state of the coronavirus in the community.

More details of the plan can be found on the Brown Deer School District website.

Cedarburg School District

Starting Sept. 8, students will have the option of either attending school in-person five days a week or virtual learning five days a week from home, the district's updated re-opening plan says.

The district plans to have a Monday through Friday schedule with the primary mode of instruction taking place at school with social distancing measures. The updated plan was presented at the Cedarburg School Board's July 29 meeting. .

Staff and students will be required to wear masks when indoors and/or when social distancing can't be maintained. The Cedarburg School Board voted 5-1 to require masks for everyone after a petition was started by Cedarburg High School students. It had 1,462 signatures.

Staff and students are also expected to monitor for any respiratory symptoms such as cough and shortness of breath, new loss or taste of smell every morning and throughout the day. These are common symptoms of COVID-19. If students are experiencing any symptoms, they should stay home from school. Signs encouraging hand washing and sanitizing, as well as hand washing/sanitizing stations, will be within schools.

The window to select either the in-person or virtual learning option begins July 31 and runs through Aug. 7. The board is planning to have a final plan approved Aug. 19.

Cudahy School District

The Cudahy School Board approved a plan July 27 providing families with two options: an in-person learning model with remote/blended learning as needed to maintain safety measures, as well as a full-time, virtual learning model.

The in-person model would see elementary and middle school students attend school four days a week Monday through Thursday. Students would do independent learning activities at home on Friday, which would also be used as a day to clean all school buildings. Cudahy High School students will attend school in-person two days a week and virtually two days a week. Students whose last names begin with A-L will attend school in-person on Monday and Tuesday and students whose last names begin with M-Z will attend on Wednesday and Thursday.

For more information on the plan, visit www.cudahysd.org/district/ReOpening.cfm.

Elmbrook School District

The district's reopening plan will include a return to full, in-person instruction five days a week, the Elmbrook School Board decided in a narrow 4-3 vote Aug. 11.

The district will open the first week of school Sept. 1-4 in a soft start mode to learn safety protocols and risk mitigation procedures for in-person instruction and transition to five-days-a-week in-person and virtual instructional models beginning Sept. 8.

Parents and staff will receive surveys asking them to declare their learning model preference, in-person or virtual. Staff will have until Aug. 14 and parents will have until Aug. 16 to decide.

More information can be found at www.elmbrookschools.org/community/learninghub.

Fox-Point Bayside School District

The Fox Point-Bayside School Board approved on July 28 a hybrid model to reopen its schools.

The main model, according to a letter from Superintendent Jeff Dellutri, is an A/B day cohort model with students in the first half of the alphabet (keeping households together) attending in-person Monday and Wednesday, and for virtual instruction Tuesday and Thursday and unstructured learning Friday. Students in the second half of the alphabet (also keeping households together) will attend in-person Tuesday and Thursday while having virtual instruction Monday and Wednesday and unstructured learning Friday. The only difference from the A/B cohort model schedule is that K4 and K5 students will attend four days per week, Monday through Thursday, with unstructured learning Friday.

Any student can opt out of the A/B day cohort model and attend the virtual only model, every day, Mondays through Thursdays with unstructured learning Fridays.

The district is also requiring masks to be worn by all students, staff and school visitors on all district property to start the school year.

Franklin Public Schools

The district plans to return to in-person instruction five days a week this fall and follow its regular schedule for student attendance. Students with medical conditions or students who live with a family member with a medical condition that could be at risk due to COVID-19 are eligible for virtual learning at home.

A majority of parents supported a full and consistent five-day-a-week return to school over a schedule that mixes virtual and in-person instruction, according to a report on a survey.

Universal precautions will focus on modified movement patterns, protocols for hand washing/sanitizing and personal protective equipment. Staff are required to wear masks or face shields when they come within 6 feet of someone with additional protocols for where and when they can be removed. Students are required to wear masks during portions of the day, including passing times, entry/exit into the building and other high traffic areas. Additional student mask wearing protocols will be developed closer to the start of school.

Germantown School District

The district will have both a face-to-face classroom experience and virtual option for students. The plan is still being finalized. A survey will be sent to all parents on which option they prefer.

Glendale-River Hills School District

The district will start the school year virtually. A plan is being developed to phase students into on-campus learning.

Grafton School District

Students will return to school for face-to-face instruction, with health measures, with a virtual learning option available.

The district also changed the wording of its policy on masks from "students will wear face coverings" to "students must wear face coverings," but gave staff discretion as to when to require students to wear face masks.

Specifically, students will wear masks when its not feasible to social distance indoors, while riding the school bus, when arriving at school and classrooms and during dismissal while walking from classrooms to outdoors, if exhibiting symptoms of illness (including fever, chills and loss of taste). Staff members are required to wear face masks while moving through the schools and in classrooms or outdoors when social distancing is not feasible.

Elementary students, whether attending virtually or in person, will be assigned a homeroom teacher. Virtual learners will take their reading, writing and math classes live and will do other classes, such as science and social studies, on their own time. At school, physical education classes will be held either outdoors or in gyms with more space.

Secondary students who are doing the virtual learning option will also take their classes live and will follow the schedule consistent with in-person learning. Virtual students may be assigned alternative activities based on the specific material needs to complete in-person tasks. The experience of performance-related courses such as automotives, culinary, music, STEM and art may be significantly different in the virtual setting.

Greendale School District

Greendale Schools is offering families a choice of in-person or fully digital learning when school resumes Sept. 1, according to its reopening plan, which can be found here.

For elementary school students, in-person learning will be four days a week in-person, with Wednesdays being a digital learning day for 'specials classes' and a deep-cleaning of the school buildings, according to Kitty Goyette, communications director for Greendale Schools.

For middle and high school students, students who are enrolled for in-person learning will be divided into groups, so appropriate social distancing can occur. Those groups will meet in-person two days a week, with digital learning planned for the other three days, and Wednesday being designated for deep cleaning.

At all levels, students learning in-person will be placed in learning groups of approximately 15 students in a regular classroom to allow for physical distancing, Goyette said.

Students who are enrolled in digital learning will be assigned to a fully digital class from 8:45 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. each day.

The health guidelines for the district can be found here.

Greenfield School District

Greenfield will begin with an all virtual setting at all grade levels, with a gradual phase-in to in-person learning beginning with elementary students, followed by middle school, and then high school, according to a school board document.

The start date for the year will also move back a week to Sept. 8.

"The virtual learning environment will be significantly different from what students experienced this spring during the time of emergency remote learning and all learning will be facilitated by School District of Greenfield teachers, using the district’s curriculum," the document said.

The board will meet on Sept. 28 to plan when to phase back to in-person classes.

Parents can also choose to send their children to school virtually for the entire fall semester if:

their child/children has a documented, underlying health condition that will require them to learn virtually.

they are not comfortable sending their child/children to school.

Hamilton School District

Families will be given a choice between traditional in-person or virtual online instruction. District officials are asking families to make a selection during online registration Aug. 3-10.

During the traditional classroom setting, students will attend classes five days a week, but with many safety measures to improve social distancing and prevent the spread of COVID-19.

Classrooms will look different to provide social distancing, masks will be required and the use of common supplies and equipment will be minimized. If schools are closed because of the coronavirus, students will learn at home until it is safe to return to school.

If there is an extended school closure, school will be in session five days a week with teachers posting new instruction virtually Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday. Wednesday will be set aside for reteaching, class meetings, small groups, one-on-ones, feedback and check ins.

During virtual learning, students will work with peers and teachers online and also independent offline. Lessons will be scheduled each day to include a whole class, small group and individual activities.

Students who choose a virtual option will be able to return to an in-person model at the semester.

Hartland Lakeside School District

Parents will have the option to chose between in-person, blended and virtual learning options, according to a reopening plan.

For those who choose in-person, students will attend class five days a week. The blended option includes two days a week in person, and three days virtual. The virtual option includes five days a week virtual learning.

The first day of school for students is Sept. 1.

Parents who choose the in-person option will need to perform a daily health check, according district guidelines. Students who attend virtually will be expected to also interact with the classroom.

The school year will start with a "soft start," as students will be divided into two groups to attend the first week of school on two separate days.

"A soft start will allow teachers to meet with smaller groups of students as they acclimate them to the new routines and transition them back to school," according to the reopening plan.

Kettle Moraine School District

The district plans to start the school year with face-to-face instruction that includes health measures while allowing students at all grade levels the option to continue virtual learning.

Students returning to school for in-person instruction will have education on hand-washing, covering coughs, physical distancing and more directed movement.

The district will provide masks and face shields in its facilities. Plexiglas "sneeze shields" will also be installed in high-traffic areas such as office spaces and health rooms. Cleaning will be increased and drinking fountains will be turned off. Only bottle-fill stations will be used. Use of cubbies, lockers and locker rooms will be eliminated or modified. Arrival, dismissal and passing times will also be staggered. No field trips or visitors will be allowed. Students and staff are also expected to screen themselves at home for symptoms.

Isolation rooms will also be set up for students and staff who are symptomatic at school to stay in until they're allowed to go home. People in contact with someone who tests positive for COVID-19 will be quarantined for 14 days to mitigate the spread. Students who repeatedly disregard safety protocols will be assigned alternate learning environments and could face other repercussions.

Elementary students will be kept with their homeroom class all day, including recess and lunch. Art, music and physical education classes will be held on a weekly rotation.

Lake Country School District

Students have three options: in-person, hybrid -and virtual access to the regular classrooms live feed of instruction, discussion and peer group virtual interaction from home. In-person instruction will be five days a week. Students can change their preference of in-person or virtual at any time.

More information will be on the district's website at www.lcs.k12.wi.us.

Maple Dale-Indian Hill School District

Schools will reopen on Sept. 1 with a hybrid model that combines in-person learning two days per week and virtual learning three days per week.

One group of students will attend in-person on Mondays and Tuesdays, and another group of students will attend in-person on Thursdays and Fridays. Both groups will attend virtually on Wednesdays.

The district is tentatively planning to resume five-day, in-person learning on Oct. 5. The district will also allow a virtual option for families.

Menomonee Falls School District

The Menomonee Falls School Board approved a plan July 27 to offer two choices to students and their families.

The first choice is instruction that could move between three models — in-person, hybrid or virtual — using a decision matrix of health indicators and attendance. No parent action is required.

The second choice is a fully-virtual learning model for a one-semester commitment. Registration was required before Aug. 3.

More information about the instructional models can be found here.

Mequon-Thiensville School District

The district has decided to start the school year with virtual learning after previously deciding to start in-person.

In a letter to district parents, district superintendent Matthew Joynt said the Mequon-Thiensville School Board voted Aug. 17 to start the year virtually due to the current state of COVID-19 spread in the Mequon-Thiensville zip codes.

Joynt said the district's goal remains to return to on campus instruction for the 2020-21 school year as soon as possible, saying the district will continue to provide updates on its website.

Merton School District

The district will discuss and vote on its reopening plan at its Aug. 3 school board meeting.

At this time, the district is continuing to plan its schools around the idea of Waukesha County's “Stay Safe to Stay Open.” The district will comply will all state mandates such as the mandatory mask mandate.

The district will have as much social distancing as possible, restructure staff and student movement throughout the day before and after school, new hand washing, sanitizing and cleaning practices throughout the district and develop instructional methods and practices to maintain distance between students and staff.

Milwaukee Public Schools

Students will begin the year online and return to the classroom in phases when the coronavirus has subsided.

The Milwaukee Public Schools board approved the $90 million plan July 16.

The school year will begin on virtual platforms on Aug. 17 or Sept. 1, depending on their school calendar. The online phase is projected to last 30 to 45 days, after which students would alternate two days in school and three online at home, and then fully return to classes once that was deemed safe.

Mukwonago Area School District

As of July 27, when the school board affirmed its approach with coronavirus mitigation measures, Mukwonago schools plan to open to face-to-face, five-day-per-week in-person learning on Sept. 1.

"While we will seek a traditional reopening to the greatest extent possible, clearly there will be mitigation measures in place to ensure the safety of our students, staff, and community," the district said on its website.

The district will, however, offer a virtual learning option for concerned parents. The website includes links to a slideshow presentation of that option for 5-year-old kindergarten through sixth grade and another for grades 7 to 12. A form for virtual learning options is also accessible from the website.

As for the mitigation plans, the district, noting its actions will be based on CDC guidelines, includes detailed links of what will be involved to keep school buildings relatively safe.

It's all covered in the pandemic information portion of the district website.

Muskego-Norway School District

All schools will allow students to return virtually or in-person this fall using a three-tiered plan, the Muskego-Norway School Board decided July 13.

Enrollment applications were made available to parents through a survey July 20. Students will automatically be enrolled in the district’s in-person program unless a virtual learning application has been submitted.

Precautions being taken at schools for the return of in-person learning include: provided thermometers and face masks, isolation rooms for individuals with COVID symptoms, fresh air intake, sneeze guards where distancing is limited, outdoor learning areas, virtual field trips, staggered entry and exit points and more.

Parents must reserve bus service, as the district is planning to reduce ridership. Students will be assigned seats and must wear face masks. The bus windows will remain open within reason, and a ventilation system will help to circulate the air.

Tier 1 of the plan offers families in-person and remote options. The start of the school year will be used to teach and practice distancing protocols. Face coverings will be provided for students and staff.

Tier 2 — which would begin if coronavirus concerns increase — would see elementary and middle school students attend in-person classes in small groups using virtual instruction. High school students would alternate weekly between in-person and virtual instruction.

Tier 3 would have all students learning from home.

According to the district’s survey data, 82% of parents and 79% of staff prefer in-person learning.

New Berlin School District

The New Berlin School Board approved in-person learning five days a week with a virtual learning option available for the first semester during an administration and re-entry task force presentation July 20.

The district will require staff to wear face masks; however, students are only encouraged to wear them, according to the district’s presentation draft. Administrators will consider mandatory mask wearing for students in grades four through 12 based on guidance from health officials.

Safety recommendations made during the presentation include: open classroom doors, assigned bus seats, encouraged distancing during recess, designated lunchtime eating areas with grab-and-go school-provided meals, signs to remind students not to share supplies and more.

A hybrid learning model will be considered if health concerns become heightened. This method would assign students to two groups, with one group learning in person Mondays and Tuesdays and the other on Thursdays and Fridays. All students would learn virtually on Wednesdays while the building is deep-cleaned.

Families will receive a survey July 27 that includes virtual and in-person enrollment options for fall. According to a school district family survey with 3,055 responses, in-person learning was preferred by 63.5% of elementary respondents and 56% of secondary respondents.

Nicolet Union High School District

The Nicolet School Board voted July 27 to start the school year with remote learning with the goal of eventually progressing to phase three, an in-person model, when health and safety allow for it.

During the remote model, all classes will have an expectation to engage in both real-time, face-to-face or recorded or self-paced, learning activities. Students will have set learning expectations and regular daily attendance, grades, work and assessments will all be tracked.

In phase two, students split time between in-school and remote learning. Students would be divided into two groups, A and B, attending school on A and B days. Half the district's students would attend in-person classes in the morning on A days, while the other half — the B group — would learn remotely. The roles would flip on B days and the B group would attend in-person classes in the morning and the A group would learn remotely. All students would learn remotely in the afternoon every day. A remote-only learning option will be available for families who do not feel comfortable having their children return to school.

During phase three, all students spend their time in the school building and resume a mostly normal school day schedule. This would involve enhanced cleaning protocols, adjustments to how students enter and exit buildings and changes to lunch services. A remote-only learning option will also be available during this phase.

North Lake School District

The school will reopen for students for in-person instruction five days a week beginning Sept. 1.

Desks and tables will be positioned 3 to 6 feet apart to provide protection for staff and students, according to the district's website.

The district will also have yellow tape in the building to ensure two-lane traffic in the hallways.

The district is also allowing virtual learning for special circumstances.

Oak Creek-Franklin School District

After originally deciding to return in-person five days a week, the Oak Creek-Franklin School Board has decided to start the year remotely and implement phases for returning face-to-face due to current COVID-19 rates in the community.

In a letter to parents on the district's website, the district said its teachers will provide a daily schedule with instructional time, office hours for students and parents, synchronous (live) and asynchronous (non-live) instruction with specified minutes and implement grade level learning requirements for remote learning. Live lessons will be recorded for students to review if they are not able to attend the synchronous lesson. Asynchronous instruction will consist of recorded instruction with learning activities to be completed and submitted to teachers. Student engagement and completion of assignments will be part of a student's attendance.

The district said it considers attendance an important measure of student engagement and a predictor of student success. Students will be considered absent if they do not attend the synchronous lessons or complete assignments or asynchronous assignments. Staff will follow-up with absent students.

More information is available on the district website.

Oconomowoc Area School District

The Oconomowoc School Board voted 5-2 Aug. 4 to start the school year with a cohort model at the elementary level and an every other day, split attendance model called the Purple and Gold Model at the intermediate and high school levels, with the board revisiting this decision every two weeks when school is started after a review of local health conditions and school level health data with input from the district's medical advisory committee.

The elementary level plan will see a group of students assigned to one primary teacher. The students will remain as static as possible throughout the day. Specials staff will rotate into the primary classroom of the cohort unless a classroom or learning space is deemed safe for use (i.e. outdoor learning space, multi-purpose room, gymnasium).

The intermediate level plan will see students divided into two groups, Purple and Gold, based on their last name. Students with last names starting with A through K will be in the Purple Group while those with last names L through Z will be in the Gold Group. Students will attend school for a full school day on their designated group day at school. On the opposite day when an intermediate student is not at school and is working virtually, he or she will take part in both synchronous, or live, experiences and asynchronous, or non-live, learning experiences.

The high school level plan also sees students divided into two groups, Purple and Gold, based on their last names. Students with last names A through K will be in the Purple Group and students with last names L through Z will be in the Gold Group. Students will attend school for a full school day on their designated group day and then virtually on their assigned group day for that model. Some days will be College, Career and Life Readiness Days in which specific grade levels report to campus for Career, College and Life Readiness activities.

More information about the elementary level plan can be found here; the intermediate plan here and the high school plan here.

Palmyra-Eagle School District

As of early August, PEASD has chosen to hold classes five days a week in-person once school begins, though there will be a virtual option available "for those who are not ready to send their students yet," said Caitlin Kirchner, the district's public relations coordinator.

It will be an unusually tidy atmosphere that students find at school, with some outdoor classes to give students a break from mask-wearing.

"We are requiring masks by all, and upping our sanitation and cleaning practices," Kirchner said. "We hope to implement lots of outdoor learning to ease the mask requirements as we do have plenty of land for everyone to spread out safely. Our plans are to make it as safe as possible, and feel we have an advantage with our smaller class sizes.

Pewaukee School District

Pewaukee has developed two models, giving parents the option of either enrolling their children in an all-virtual program for nine-week increments or allowing them to begin under a hybrid model that district officials have called a "soft-open."

The plan, spelled out in a 28-page document on the district's website, describes the in-person hybrid model in which students attend school partly in a virtual setting and partly in-person, progressing through a series of three phases ending in full daily attendance.

"The reason for the 'soft-open' approach is we will have an extensive plan of procedures, protocols and alterations to our practices that will take some time for staff and students to learn, apply and refine," Superintendent Mike Cady said. "This is far more manageable with smaller numbers of students on campus at any one time. Furthermore, fewer students allows much greater flexibility to employ social distancing and other virus mitigation strategies."

The first phase would involve half the students getting face-to-face instruction on Monday and Tuesday, virtual learning on Thursday and Friday, while the other half would learn their lessons on the opposite schedule. Wednesday would be fully virtual for all students during the first phase, allowing for what district officials call a "deep cleaning" of school buildings.

During the second phase, in-person learning would take place every day but Wednesday.

The all-virtual option would require nine-week commitments. The plan also has provisions for emergency remote learning.

Port Washington-Saukville School District

Students in the Port Washington-Saukville School District will be phased into the classroom through a four-step system.

Each phase is dependent on local health conditions. The school district will work with stakeholders to decide when the district should advance to the next phase.

The district will start with full-time virtual learning. In the second phase, one group of students will attend in-person class on Mondays and Tuesdays, and another group of students will attend in person on Thursdays and Fridays. Both groups will attend virtually on Wednesdays.

The third phase will bring students back to the classroom four days per week, with a virtual learning option for students who are unable to attend in-person instruction.

The fourth phase of the plan will bring students back to school for full-time, in-person instruction five days per week.

Students will be given the opportunity to temporarily remove their masks when the staff determines it can be done so safely.

Students who refuse to wear a mask when asked will be referred to virtual education and will need to wait until the start of the next semester to apply for in-person learning.

Richmond School District

Students in the Richmond School District can choose virtual or in-person learning. If it is done virtually, they will be in that environment for a trimester.

Masks will be required and sanitizing stations upon entering and existing buildings will be utilized for in-person instruction. Only one grade will be in the cafeteria at lunch with social distancing and sanitizing before and after lunch. Large indoor and outdoor spaces will be used for learning to increase social distancing.

Virtual instruction will be assigned if a child tests positive for COVID-19 as well as if someone in the same household does or if someone has been in close contact with someone who tests positive for COVID-19.

Shorewood School District

Students will start the school year with a virtual+ learning model, the Shorewood School Board unanimously approved July 28.

The first day of school will be Sept. 8, and the virtual+ learning model will be in effect at least through Nov. 6, when the district will reassess using gating criteria, a news release from the district said.

The virtual+ learning model will provide live video classes in which students will have structured schedules to attend live classes with teachers, along with time for teachers and students to check in on any questions and concerns.

There will also be scheduled in-person access to school buildings and staff for small group and individual education, therapy and counseling services. Masks, social distancing and cleaning of indoor spaces between uses will be required when students and staff are on campuses.

There will also be limited student supervision at school for families who cannot be home during daytime virtual learning hours. Due to the district's limited capacity, the service is only for students and families who have no other options for child supervision during the school day.

South Milwaukee School District

Students will start the first six weeks of school learning remotely, the school board approved Aug. 5.

An update will be provided by the board by Sept. 25.

The fall virtual learning program differs from the spring program. New remote teaching additions include: daily assignments, scheduled live classes, monitored attendance and engagement, required classwork and more.

Meetings with parents, students and teachers will also be virtual through “launchpad meetings” for elementary families between Sept. 1-11, and morning meetings/closing circles for teachers and students at the start and end of each school day.

Virtual plan schedules for elementary and high school students can be seen on pages 13 and 26, respectively, of the South Milwaukee School District’s presentation.

St. Francis School District

The St. Francis School District will start the school year virtually with a reassessment date of Sept. 15, according to Mark Elworthy, superintendent of the St. Francis School District.

However, for anyone on school property now, all individuals must wear face coverings unless the person is alone in a private office.

Students will use the educational platforms SeeSaw (K4-3) and Schoology (4-12). These platforms will provide a conferencing solution that will be used by teachers, the district says.

If in-person instruction resumes, the district is asking families to self-screen their symptoms every day before attending school.

Stone Bank School

Though the details are far from final as of Aug. 1, Stone Bank School in Oconomowoc has told parents in a letter that it plans on offering a mix of face-to-face, blended and virtual learning once the school year begins.

According to the letter by Superintendent Ryan Krohn, those plans will be finalized in the weeks ahead, following an Aug. 17 school board meeting. A survey that will be sent to parents on Aug. 18 will also help the district finalize its plans.

The survey will query what options parents prefer and what safety precautions matter most for each student in their households.

Krohn acknowledged the situation is somewhat fluid, for now.

Either way, any in-person instruction will involve a mix of face mask requirements, social distancing and hand sanitation initiatives based on guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Waukesha County Public Health Department, Krohn said in the letter.

Virtual and blended-learning plans are in the works as well, though very little information was available as of early August.

Swallow School District

According to Superintendent Melissa Thompson, the school board's goal remains to reopen Swallow School for face-to-face instruction five days per week, but "with the understanding that a flexible virtual option will likely be needed for some students all of the time, and a fully virtual option may be needed for all students some of the time."

The Hartland school will use strategies set forth by the Waukesha County Health Public Department and CDC.

Waukesha School District

On Aug. 12, the school board opted for a hybrid model for middle and high school students, who will attend classes virtually on Monday and alternate between in-person and virtual learning Tuesday through Friday.

For elementary school grades, students will learn in-person all week, with the district allowing parents to opt for all-virtual learning to alleviate their concerns.

In a 5-4 vote, the board opted for those details and opted not to adapt a phased-in opening plan that would have began with virtual learning and slowly worked learning plans back to daily in-person classroom settings.

Even with face-to-face learning, the scene won't be quite like the traditional classroom setting. According to a chart previously explaining the options facing parents, it would involve virus mitigation efforts, including required face coverings for both teachers and students, social distancing and temperatures checks of each student, and plenty of hand sanitizing.

Wauwatosa School District

The Wauwatosa School Board voted 6-1 on July 27 to start the school year with two options: a phased, in-person option and a virtual learning option.

The first phase will see staff get used to the learning environment and safety procedures. Phase two will see students get used to the learning environment and safety procedures and include student and staff cohorts. Student cohorts would attend school two days a week. Phase three is the first full week of school, and it involves a hybrid model. Phase four involves ongoing learning. Options available depending on a medical/public health advisory panel's standards and metrics include classroom learning, which would see a five-day, in-person instruction model; a hybrid model in which students learn at school two days per week and learn virtually from home three days per week, and a virtual learning option in which students do online learning from home four days a week.

Students and staff will be required to wear masks, which will be provided to those who don't have one. Breaks and other strategies such as contests and games will be incorporated to help the transition at the lower levels. Other health measures include the installation of extra hand-washing and sanitation stations, improving air circulation and quality, increased cleaning and sanitizing of school buildings, student and family self-screening for symptoms and social distancing measures such as furniture reconfiguration in classrooms.

West Allis-West Milwaukee School District

Students will return to school Sept. 8 in an all virtual learning format, the West Allis-West Milwaukee School Board on July 27 decided.

Then, depending on health metrics, the district plans to move to distance learning, with two days per week in school and finally in-person learning, which would be five days per week for elementary students and four days per week for secondary students, a district news release said.

Parents are asked to select a specific option for their children so the district can plan for once it moves past being all virtual.

Students and staff will be required to wear masks in schools or on buses when social distancing isn't possible. The district has the inventory to provide each staff member and student with two masks and will provide clear face shields for students and teachers when educationally necessary.

Whitefish Bay School District

Whitefish Bay students will resume school with a hybrid model that combines in-person learning two days per week and virtual learning for three days per week. The district will also allow a full virtual option for families.

Students with last names starting with A through L will attend school in-person on Monday and Tuesday, and the remainder of the students will attend school in-person on Thursday and Friday. Both groups of students will attend virtually on Wednesday.

The school district plans to use the hybrid model until the end of the first quarter, at which point the school board will determine whether a change in format is appropriate.

Classrooms will be limited to 13 desks to provide enough space for physical distancing. Face coverings will be required for everyone inside the buildings, except students who need medical exceptions.

Visitors will be limited those deemed as essential. Meetings will be held virtually when possible.

The full plan is available on the district website.

Whitnall School District

The Whitnall School Board voted Aug. 17 to approve its reopening plan of in-person learning with health measures, along with a virtual option for families who want it, a letter to parents said.

During the first week of school Sept. 1-4, students, regardless of whether they chose the in-person or virtual learning option, will attend school one day that week. This will allow students to meet their teachers, access the new learning management system with teacher support and pick up their technology/supplies.

All students will attend school daily beginning Sept. 8.

More info can be found at www.whitnall.com/district/covid-19-response-.cfm.

- Reporters Annysa Johnson, Jim Riccioli, Cathy Kozlowicz, Evan Casey and Jeff Rumage contributed to this report.

Contact Alec Johnson at (262) 875-9469 or alec.johnson@jrn.com. Follow him on Twitter at @AlecJohnson12.

search_result.title: Coronavirus in Vermont: Latest news and impact
search_result.text:
Free Press Staff

As the situation surrounding the COVID-19 caused by the new coronavirus continues to evolve in Vermont, here are updates and information. The latest news is at the top.

Symptoms of COVID-19 can include fever, cough and breathing trouble. Most develop only mild symptoms. But some people, usually those with other medical complications, develop more severe symptoms, including pneumonia, which can be fatal.

Tuesday, July 21, 2020

Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the financial outlook for the Burlington International Airport is stable, the airport announced Tuesday.

Moody's Investors Service affirmed the airport's Baa2 credit rating with the stable outlook earlier this month. The rating, according to Moody's, means the airport's obligations are medium-grade and subject to moderate credit risk, but that it has a strong ability to repay short-term debt obligations.

________________

Property taxes for Williston residents will be a bit higher than expected this year due to effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The pandemic delayed construction in the town, which impacted property values, the town stated in a news release. As a result, grand list increases were less than initially estimated.

The new rate is set to $0.2750, meaning that for every $100,000 in property value, municipal taxes will be $275, the town said. The deadline for the first property tax payment has been postponed from Aug. 15 until Sept 15. The other two deadlines will remain the same.

________________

Monday, July 20, 2020

Three full-time staff were laid off at Colchester Parks and Recreation due to diminished demand for camps and recreation programs during the pandemic, Town Manager Aaron Frank announced last week.

"Please do what you can to help towards positive changes in COVID outcomes that will allow us to bring back these valuable programs and staff that help make Colchester a great place to live, work and play," Frank wrote in a newsletter.

On a more upbeat note, the town announced that rehabilitation work on the Colchester Causeway is moving along ahead of schedule. If the trend holds, the breathtaking walk/bike trail across a portion of Lake Champlain will re-open by early September.

________________

Ten new cases of COVID-19 were reported to the state's health department Monday morning, bringing the cumulative state total to 1,360.

Three people are currently hospitalized with the virus, the same number as yesterday. Nineteen other hospitalizations are being investigated.

Deaths have remained at 56 since June 18.

Total people recovered are 1,139 and a total of 83,868 people have been tested.

_________________

The lakefront ECHO nature and science center in Burlington has waived its entrance fees to the public through Sept. 14, thanks to a fundraising effort by its members.

Although there is no cost for admission, tickets — available online — are required, the center reported in a news release.

ECHO is open 10 a.m. - noon, and 1-3 p.m., Friday - Monday.

Beginning July 24, the center will reserve the 10 a.m. - noon slot as a "member-preferred" time for visits.

________________

A new drop-off center for recycling and trash will open in Hinesburg on Saturday, according to an update posted today by Chittenden Solid Waste District.

The new facility at 907 Beecher Hill Road features a more efficient layout and up-to-date compactors that will help reduce truck traffic, wrote CSWD spokesperson Alise Certa.

Hours: 8 a.m. - 3:30 p.m., Saturdays only for now.

Safety: All customers must wear masks and stay six feet apart.

Restrictions: No bulky items (mattresses, furniture, construction material) at this time.

Check CSWD's website for a locator map, and more guidelines.

The district's drop-off centers in Richmond and Burlington remain closed due to COVID-19 restrictions.

=================

Sunday, July 19, 2020

An gathering to paint a Black Lives Matter mural on Burlington's Main Street between St. Paul Street and South Winooski Avenue was planned from 2-3 p.m. Sunday. The mural was approved by city councilors and multiple city departments took part in organizing and undertaking the event.

___________

Twelve new cases of COVID-19 were reported to the health department, bringing the cumulative state total to 1,350. Three people are currently hospitalized with the virus, one less than the previous day.

21 other hospitalizations are being investigated.

Deaths remained at 56.

Total people recovered are 1,137 and a total of 82,500 people have been tested.

___________

The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Sunday for the Burlington area, with high humidity and temperatures soaring near 100 degrees.

The forecast calls for a high of 98 degrees, with the heat index — a measure of the combined affect of heat and humidity — topping out at 101.

Saturday, July 18, 2020

Three new cases of COVID-19 were reported to the health department, bringing the cumulative state total to 1,338. Four people are currently hospitalized with the virus, one less than the previous day.

21 other hospitalizations are being investigated.

Deaths remained at 56.

Total people recovered are 1,125 and a total of 80,446 people have been tested.

___________

Friday, July 17, 2020

Nine new cases of COVID-19 were reported to the Health Department. The recovery total is 1,121.

The cumulative state total of cases is now at 1,334.

The deaths remain at 56, and the number currently hospitalized is 4.

88,246 people have been tested.

The state listed the following updates on its dashboard:

"July 17 The number of people tested is incorrect and will be updated later this afternoon. July 16 The number of people tested displayed in the dashboard dropped by less than 300 people due to a new method being used that improves the quality of the demographic information about people tested and removes duplicates. The change also affects the numbers in the 'Total People Tested' graph and 'People Tested by Day' graph. A new map on the dashboard, 'Percent of Population Tested by County,' shows the percent of residents by county that have been tested."

___________

Takeaways from Gov. Scott's Friday news conference include the following:

Vermont's Health Commissioner Dr. Mark Levine gave an update on the Manchester situation (with 59 people who had positive antigen tests): 17 had PCR tests, "which is recommended to confirm the positive antigen result." Of this group, two tested positive .

School re-openings: Scott said he expects Vermont will use a hybrid model featuring remote and in-person learning. Dr. William Raszka with the UVM Health Network noted children seem less likely to transmit the virus that causes COVID-19. State Epidemiologist Dr. Patsy Kelso named strategies like: daily screenings; testing symptomatic people; contact tracing; using physical distancing and facial coverings.



___________

The Fletcher Free Library announced updated services in a July 16 news release.

These include allowing scheduled computer time, "brief visits to collect materials and receive library support" and outdoor seating ("when staffing allows").

The library has a Kids' Open Air Hours service that will allow youth to pick and chat about books.

"Weather permitting, the FFL Youth Department will staff a table on the library lawn in front of the historic Carnegie building at 235 College Street on Saturdays from 10:30 am to 12:30 pm and Wednesdays from 1 to 3 pm," the news release stated. "FFL requests that participants wear masks and maintain social distance."

The library also has mystery bags with youth books.

"The bags are available at Open Air Hours and at the front desk and the list of themes is on the Kids’ webpage at fletcherfree.org," the news release stated. "There is no bag limit."

___________

Thursday, July 16, 2020

Nine new cases of COVID-19 were reported to the Health Department. Seven people have recovered, bringing the cumulative recovery total to 1,111.

The cumulative state total of cases is now at 1,325.

The deaths remain at 56, and the number currently hospitalized remains at 5.

79,040 have been tested.

___________

Wednesday, July 15, 2020

Thirteen new cases of COVID-19 were reported to the health department, bringing the cumulative state total to 1,318. Five people are currently hospitalized with the virus, three more than the previous day.

Fourteen other hospitalizations are being investigated.

Deaths remained at 56.

Total people recovered are 1,104 and a total of 78,358 people have been tested.

___________

Those who file a new initial claim for unemployment insurance may receive a call from the Department of Labor to confirm their identity and intent to file.

"This extra step is being taken to protect Vermonters against fraudulent filers using their personal information," a news release from the Department of Labor said. Imposter fraud has been on the rise across the country, according to the labor department.

"Individuals may ask the Department’s call center representative to provide further information to identify themselves, or if they do not feel comfortable providing information to the representative, the claimant can call the trusted Claimant Assistance Line at 877-214-3332 and select ‘Identity Confirmation’ from the menu options to connect with a call center representative," the release states.

Those who do not validate their identity when contacted may see a delay in payments.

__________

The Burlington city building at 625 Pine St. is open for limited, in-person services.

Burlington residents can do business with Public Works, Permitting & Inspections and Parks, Recreation & Waterfront Tuesday through Friday, 7 a.m. to 3 p.m.

Visitors are required to wear masks, not to exceed four customers in the lobby and sign a log book.

"While the City still encourages the public to conduct as much business over the phone or internet as possible in the interest of public health, we also recognize the value of serving the public directly," the news release says.

How to contact (online, email and phone):

__________

Tuesday, July 14, 2020

Gov. Phil Scott announced Tuesday that Vermont's Health Care Provider Stabilization Grant Program will launch on Friday, July 17. The program utilizes up to $275 million from the federal Coronavirus Relief Fund to provide direct cash grants to eligible health care and human service providers who have lost revenue or incurred increased expenses because of the COVID-19 crisis.

The Agency of Human Services and the Department of Vermont Health Access will host a webinar on Monday, July 20, to explain the grant application process, eligibility requirements and the documents providers should plan to submit when applying for a grant. Sign up here to receive an email when the application is open.

_________

Four new cases of COVID-19 were reported Tuesday morning by the Vermont Department of Health, bringing the cumulative total for the state to 1,305.

Two people were hospitalized with the virus — the same number as the previous day. Eight hospitalizations are under investigation. Deaths remain at 56.

The health department is reporting 1,099 Vermonters who have recovered from the disease, with a total of 77,624 people have been tested.

_________

A preliminary outbreak of COVID-19 cases in Windham County was announced by state officials Tuesday during Gov. Phil Scott's weekly news conference.

Over 30 "presumptively positive" cases have been reported by Manchester Medical Center, said Health Commissioner Mark Levine, after the center's urgent care conducted a series of antigen tests to regional residents.

Those that test positive on antigen tests, which differ from PCR tests, are "not considered to be a lab-confirmed test" said Levine. Antigen tests tend to not be included in Vermont's number of cases, and those that were either confirmed positive or "false negatives" would need to be tested by the Health Department.

Levine stated that the Health Department has already set up a pop-up site in Londonderry for July 15, and he encouraged those that tested positive, as well as others in the region to attend it.

In regards to the outbreak, Mike Smith, secretary of the state's Agency of Human Services, cautioned Vermonters against failing to quarantine after traveling to "hotspots" outside of the state's designated safe areas. He further went on to recommend residents should not attend social events or gatherings following those trips where they know they are "bound to have close contacts" with other people.

"It is a pattern that I'm starting to get a little concerned about," said Smith.

"We all need to do our part. Risky behavior can lead to outbreaks."

Both Levine and Smith were hesitant to call it "the Manchester outbreak", citing that where people were getting tested did not reflect where they had contracted the virus.

_________

Gov. Phil Scott announced Tuesday that he would be extending Vermont's state of emergency through August 15. The action will not roll back opening-up procedures, Scott said — but will provide a mechanism through which the administration can update guidelines as necessary.

_________

Two statewide grant programs — aimed at providing relief to Vermont's dairy industry and health care system — were announced Tuesday.

The Vermont COVID-19 Agriculture Assistance Program will be offering a total of $25 million in federal funding to dairy producer and processors stating Friday, July 17.

Those eligible include dairy farmers and processors who were operating as of March 1 and were subsequently impacted by the pandemic, either through income loss, additional expenses or market disruption of dairy prices.

An estimated 25 Vermont dairies have closed operations since March 1, according to Anson Tebbetts, secretary of the sate's Agency of Agriculture, Food and Markets, during the governor's news conference. Prior to the pandemic, the state saw a loss of 1.5 farms per month.

"This has been a direct result of what happened when the markets went away for our dairy farmers," Tebbetts said.

Applications are available via the Agency's website, and must be completed by Oct. 1.

--------------

The Health Care Stabilization Grant Program is additionally set to launch this Friday, intended to give $275 million of financial assistance to Vermont health care providers.

Applications must be completed by August 15, and will be evaluated and distributed based on "demonstrated need", as opposed to a first come, first serve basis.

The program is intended to cover a wide variety of providers, organizations and small-scale practices including health centers, dentists, mental health and substance abuse treatment providers, physical therapists, and emergency medical service providers.

"We want to continue to meet the needs of providers during and after this time of crisis," said Mike Smith, secretary of the state's Agency of Human Services. "If providers are not certain if they are eligible, we want them to apply anyway."

Cash grants for the first round of this program will cover expenses between March 1 and June 15. The second round is expected to launch in October, and will cover between June 16 to Sept. 30.

_________

Burlington School District will host a series of town hall meetings this week, inviting community members to learn about and participate in the district's plans to reopen schools this fall.

The meetings will be conducted virtually via Zoom and split between two days to allow both families and staff the opportunity to ask questions and hear from school administrators about the reopening.

The town hall meeting for families will meet 7 p.m. on July 15, whereas a meeting for staff will be conducted the following day, at 7 p.m. on July 16.

“This is a key moment in our planning process," said Tom Flanagan, the new superintendent for Burlington School District when began his tenure on July 1st.

"We need to hear from the community in order to finalize our plans and inform our families so they can start planning their lives."

For more information, those interested can visit the district's website via this link. The meeting will also be aired live through the district's YouTube and Facebook pages. Interpreters will be available to translate the meeting.

Monday, July 13, 2020

Six new cases of COVID-19 were reported Monday by the Vermont Department of Health, which brings the cumulative total for the state to 1,301.

Two people were hospitalized with the virus — the same number as the previous day. Eight hospitalizations are under investigation.

Deaths remained the same at 56. There has not been a COVID-related death in Vermont since June 18.

The health department is reporting 1,096 Vermonters who have recovered from the disease.

76,581 people have been tested for the virus.

NOTE: The Free Press noticed the numbers regarding new and total case counts didn't align from July 11 to July 13 and subsequently reached out to the Health Department. Ben Truman with the department said in an email that this is why there is a notice that this data is preliminary. He provided an example: A person who tested positive might no longer get counted if it is learned that they don't live in Vermont.

_________

Sunday, July 12, 2020

Fourteen new cases of COVID-19 were reported Sunday by the Vermont Department of Health, which brings the cumulative total for the state to 1,296.

Two people were hospitalized with the virus — the same number as the previous day. Fifteen hospitalizations are under investigation.

Deaths remained the same at 56. There has not been a COVID-related death in Vermont since June 18.

The health department is reporting 1,089 Vermonters who have recovered from the disease.

75,851 people have been tested for the virus.

__________

Saturday, July 11, 2020

Six new cases of COVID-19 were reported Saturday by the Vermont Department of Health, which brings the cumulative total for the state to 1,283.

Two people were hospitalized with the virus — the same as yesterday. Sixteen hospitalizations are under investigation.

Deaths remained the same at 56. There has not been a COVID-related death in Vermont since June 18.

The health department is reporting 1,066 Vermonters who have recovered from the disease.

75,032 people have been tested for the virus.

Friday, July 10, 2020

The Governor announced $30 million in housing assistance for those impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.

The money would be allocated Federal CARES Act funding: $25 million for renters and landlords and $5 million for homeowners behind on making payments. Those interested in receiving assistance can begin applying online starting Monday July 13 for the rental assistance program or mortgage assistance program.

The semester will also end early — residential students will return home for Thanksgiving break and will take final exams remotely, the college announced Thursday.

The plan will not affect the number of teaching and learning days, the college said in a statement. The accelerated semester includes no breaks, with instruction on Labor Day and throughout October. Students will leave campus on Friday, November 20, and are planned to be welcomed back when the spring semester begins on January 19, 2021.

“We know this is different from our normal semester,” college President Elaine Collins said. “The health of the entire NVU community is our number one priority as we prepare to return to campus for face-to-face instruction.”

__________

Vermont reported an additional 16 positive cases of COVID-19 on Thursday, bringing its total to 1,110, Health Department statistics show.

According to the data, 905 people have recovered from COVID-19 and 47,209 people have been tested for the virus in Vermont.

The number of people hospitalized with the virus decreased by one on Thursday for a total of three. Nine people are hospitalized under investigation for COVID-19.

No additional deaths due to COVID-19 have occurred — that total remains at 55.

__________

No cases of COVID-19 were found at the Southern State Correctional Facility in Springfield following mass testing of inmates and staff, the Vermont Department of Corrections said.

According to Corrections officials, 336 inmates and 181 staff at the facility were tested June 8. All tests came back negative for the virus.

The Springfield-based prison was the sixth and final facility to undergo mass testing during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Northwest State Correctional Facility in St. Albans Town was the only facility to have inmates test positive for the virus since it was first detected among members of the prison population, the Corrections Department said.

__________

Wednesday, June 10, 2020

A total of 74 cases of COVID-19 are thought to be associated with the recent outbreak that emerged in Winooski, according to Vermont Department of Health data from Tuesday evening.

About 80% of those cases are in Winooski and most of the rest are in Burlington, the Health Department said. Only one in five people associated with the outbreak are reporting symptoms — the number of asymptomatic individuals is thought to be a contributing factor to the spread of the virus in the community.

There have been no deaths associated with the outbreak, the state reported.

__________

Guidance is underway to prepare Vermont schools across the state to tentatively open by Labor Day, announced Gov. Phil Scott in a press briefing Wednesday.

Health and safety measures for school districts are being developed by the state's Agency of Education and the Health Department, in collaboration with other Vermont educational organizations and pediatricians, and will be formally announced by next week.

"it's critical we finalize a plan now so we can reopen in the fall," said Scott.

Among the objectives of the guidance is to decrease the risk of COVID-19 entering school, being transmitted between staff and students, and ensuring students with certain needs are "addressed in a fair and equitable measure".

Provisions could include social distancing on busses, daily temperature screenings at bus stops and school entrances, increased testing and tracing capacity, and mandatory dismissals if students or staff display any symptoms.

"It's likely we'll have to change or amend this guidance in the coming months," said Dan French, secretary of the Agency of Education.

"We're also preparing to improve our ability to provide remote learning as a contingency."

__________

Registration is open for Vermonters seeking meals from distribution sites across the state this month.

Pick up sites are scheduled on these days in these areas , with more sites to be added for the remainder of June:

Middlebury area: June 10

Brattleboro area: June 11

Morristown area: June 12

Lyndon area: June 15

Grand Isle County: June 16

Randolph area: June 17

Dover area: June 18

Chittenden County: June 19

People can register online at humanresources.vermont.gov/food-help or over the phone via 2-1-1. Those who register will receive a time window to pick up meals at their designated site, upon which they can receive a

__________

Four people are now hospitalized with COVID-19, according to the Vermont Department of Health, double the total from 24 hours earlier.

The state recorded 11 new cases of the virus, increasing the total to 1,095 since the start of the pandemic. Fifty-seven people are being monitored for the virus. The number of deaths remains 55.

The total of tests for COVID-19 continues to jump in light of an outbreak in Winooski that has since spread to Burlington. The Health Department reports 45,742 people have been tested, up roughly 1,500 from the previous day's total.

__________

Thunder Road Speedbowl announced Tuesday that it would begin its 2020 schedule on June 18, about a month later than originally planned. The event will be held without spectators and will be broadcast pay-per-view on the Northeast Sports Network (www.nsnsports.net).

More:Thunder Road to open 2020 season with pay-per-view race on June 18

__________

Tuesday, June 9, 2020

Two people are now hospitalized with COVID-19, according to the Vermont Department of Health, up one from Monday.

The department noted 9 new cases of the virus in the past 24 hours, increasing the total to 1,084 since the pandemic began. The number of deaths remains at 55.

The total of tests for COVID-19 continues to jump in light of an outbreak in Winooski that has since spread to Burlington. The Health Department reports 44,228 people have been tested, up almost 1,500 from the previous day's total.

__________

With new cases of COVID-19 having cropped up in Winooski and Burlington in recent days, the Community Health Centers of Burlington announced several opportunities for testing in those two cities.

Testing in Burlington is from 9 a.m.-2 p.m. daily through June 12 at the O.N.E. Community Center on Allen Street. Testing in Winooski is offered from 9 a.m.-3 p.m., also through June 12, at the O'Brien Community Center on Malletts Bay Avenue except for June 11, when tests will be conducted at the Winooski Senior Center on Barlow Street.

__________

Three new college presidents, Laura Walker (Bennington College), Dr. Benjamin Ola. Akande (Champlain College) and Col. Mark Anarumo (Norwich University), took on new positions in the midst of the coronavirus.

More:Coronavirus: New college presidents to lead Champlain, Bennington, Norwich schools, communities

__________

Gov. Scott's new racial equity task force is taking applications for a public member to be appointed. The force intends to consider a few projects, one of which involves looking at support structures for diverse populations. This includes honing in on "racial disparities in health outcomes highlighted by COVID-19."

More:Vermont seeking public member for newly created racial equity task force

__________

Vermont has been awarded over $4.4 million in Emergency Solutions Grants for its population experiencing and at risk of experiencing homelessness, according to a June 9 news release from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.

This can go toward a number of uses, like providing hotel vouchers or operating emergency shelters.

“We are proud of the extraordinary efforts being made by our Vermont homeless partners to protect our most vulnerable from the impacts of COVID-19, this funding helps to further their efforts in this fight,” said David Tille, HUD New England Regional Administrator, in the news release.

__________

Monday, June 8, 2020

The total number of positive COVID-19 cases in Vermont rose by 12 to a total of 1,075, according to data released Monday by the Vermont Department of Health. About 895 people were estimated to have recovered while a total of 42,798 people had been tested for the virus.

search_result.text:
Samuel Stebbins and Michael B. Sauter

24/7 Wall Street

School district quality is one of the most important factors homebuyers consider when looking for a place to live – particularly for new or expecting parents. A good school district can greatly increase a child’s chances of future success.

Of course, the influences that can shape a child’s future are not strictly limited to the classroom. Conditions in the home and the broader community also have an effect.

Using data from the U.S. Census Bureau and the National Center for Education Statistics, 24/7 Wall St. developed an index of measures, including the child poverty rate, the teacher-to-student ratio, per-pupil spending, the share of adults with a college education, and the high school graduation rate to determine the school district where students are most likely to succeed in every state. In our analysis, we also reviewed a number of measures of district outcomes, including college entrance exam performance and subject proficiency tests from education and community data clearing house, Niche. While favorable rankings in these measures will not alone ensure children's chances for success through their school years and into adulthood, they can provide them with considerable advantages.

One of the most important predictors of a child’s academic success is their poverty status. Children living below the poverty line are more likely to report poor physical health and have reduced ability to concentrate and retain information. Childhood poverty increases the likelihood of low test scores and reduces a student’s chances of completing high school. For this reason, the child poverty rate was selected as a component in the index. Here is a state-by-state look at the child poverty rate.

It is important to note that education policy is decided largely at the state level, and partially as a result, the difference in school district quality across a state can be lower than it is between states. A district that ranks as the best in a given state will not necessarily rank favorably among districts in other states. Here is a list of the states with the best and worst schools.
